This anime is a reverse harem (lots o' guys for one girl), but she doesn't care about them. Rather, she is tied to them through debt. What's great about this show though, is the hilarious way in which they solve problems, as Haruhi plays a boy in a host club (which is basically like being a man-whore, without the sex). The comedy in here is great, but what really drives the plot home, is how the most eccentric characters are actually soft normal beings.
What's bad though, is the fact that the background stories of Hikaru and Kaoru get too serious, and really slow down thepace of the story. Plus they really seem like jackasses once their childhood is explained.\n\n
Overall I give this a 9/10, the ending was pretty bland, and the opening humor is very misleading (the humor just wasn't as good when the eps continued...Still good though).

Ouran Koukou Host Club is an amazing anime. It's extremely funny, with just the right amount of romance in it. This anime would be rated 10/10 for the style, and story line I love it so much, so if you are looking for a romantic comedy this one will have you laughing your socks off.

I'd never even heard of this show before someone brought it over to my house for an anime night. I hadn't watched any kind of "romance" shows before and didn't even know what a harem anime was, let alone all the types of characters you have in them, so this show was actually pretty educational. I learned a lot between belly laughs, and I laughed enough to add years to my life.
The premise is pretty simple, the lead female Haruhi gets into a debt with an all boy club, which is based on pleasing the other girls at school. Romantically, sheesh. Haruhi then has todress as a boy in order to work off her debt, leading to countless situations where she's mistaken as a he. Simple enough, right? Not exactly...


Seeing as this is a "reverse harem" it means everything is sort of a parody, I think. It would explained why everything is jacked up to 11 when played for laughs, such as the extremes of the other boys in the club. You have your strong and silent type, your identical twins with a cheeky side, your prince charming, the intellectual, and the younger cuter one. Everything they do becomes so outlandish and extravagant that you won't be able to stop laughing. They're the kind of people who'd have a desert themed party and fly in sand from the Sahara, just for the day. Each character has a downright charming personality, and the trouble they get into is so much fun to watch. Better still, the most successful "host" for the girls is another girl. I gotta say, my favourite part of the show is how the boys try incredibly hard to keep Haruhi's secret that she really is a girl. Try getting through a physical exam at the nurse's office!


The art style feels a bit like Revolutionary Girl Utena (read: there's a strong flower motif) which I actually really enjoyed to my surprise, while the limbs looked a little spindly for my tastes, but the show really did make it work quite well. The animation is very nice, I don't remember a single scene where something was obviously out of place or rushed. I can't say the same for the music however. Music is one of the big things I try to pay attention to, you can always tell when a lot of effort gets put into it because you get this feeling of completeness. I liked the cheesy intro theme but the ending one was like rubbing alcohol on a fresh cut, but I will admit they fit in quite well to the theme. The actual soundtrack to the show was enjoyable, but not entirely memorable. I can remember it fit nicely with the visuals, but I can't remember any specific themes or pieces.


The show itself is largely episodic, which really helps to change the setting. New episode? New party. The comedy is done so well, it's even surprisingly high brow. It never reverts to crude sex jokes, as easy as it would be, but relies instead on witty dialogue, financial separation, mistaken identity, and playing around with gender rolls. I'll admit, I was pretty weirded out when the twins pretended to be romantically involved, but then the penny dropped and I couldn't stop laughing at their acting. If you're familiar with harem personality types, you'll enjoy how committed each character stays to them. If you're like me, this is a great title to try to see if they're for you. The final few episodes I really enjoyed, they added just a splash of extra emotional depth to the main lead characters and the closing scene did tug a bit on my heart strings. By the end of this show, I ended up enjoying it so much that I bought the DVD so I could share it with others. This is a show best enjoyed with friends.

Albeit skeptical, I found myself absolutely in love with Ouran High School Host Club after the first episode. It only took me seven years to convince myself to give it a shot, right? 
The most admirable aspect of this anime is the character development and serious tones which somehow manage to blissfully accompany the pleasant heart warming comedy. Only pictures sit still in time; it's up to each individual to decide if how much or how little they'd like their world to change. By the end of this anime, you'll be strongly re-enforced with the cliche idea that it's okay to be yourself.
Story (8/10}: Atypical, not so typical reverse harem situation where the main character Haruhi (a girl) enters a host club. In this club, the rich boys cater to rich girls needs and desires, i.e they entertain them with their dazzling charm and corny lines. On the other hand, Haruhi is a "commoner" who can't help but face-palm at the silliness of which the rich depict the commoners lives to be like. Needless to say, Haruhi finds herself staying with these members for quite a bit of time, the more she helps them, the more she finds herself being helped. 


Sound {9/10}: The opening was amiable, it gave a sense of "welcome", beckoning the viewer to please let go of their troubles and indulge themselves into the anime. The ending was oddly beautiful; it seemed to send a message of growth, as if pushing someone forward into another action that has yet to be taken. 

Character voices whether Japanese OR English were pretty spot in in my opinion. Haruhi's voice was extremely fitting in both situations for her "gender neutral character", and the twins had slightly(depending on language) different voices but were able to, with ease, make them sound similar when they joined in unison. The back ground music in specific scenes fit perfectly, especially during the few serious moments.


Art (10/10): Can you believe it? This art was done in 2006; it could easily be dismissed as a 2013 anime! The characters were drawn wonderfully, with intent to appeal to the viewers. The characters facial expressions were hilarious at times, and when the few serious moments came everything seemed to fade away leaving nothing but a serious subtle tone. 


Characters (10/10): Aren't characters the key components to successful anime? What they say, do, think, feel, that is what is the catalyst to every event that takes place. Each character is funny in their own way; whether it is by their actions, words, or even expressions. Yet they all seem to have a hidden in-depth past, filled with a variety of dark and happy events. Regardless, they are all lovable and likable. Their actions are always supported by their personality, even if that personality has yet to be revealed; it will be explained. The twins were probably the most prominent example of character growth. 


Enjoyment & Overall (10/10): I can't help it! The anime made me laugh far too much, and it even tugged a heart string once or twice! The symbolism of growth and bonds of friendship where oh so cheesy but fitting. Rambling aside, this was a prime example of a successful comedy which laughably mocked its own genre whilst perfectly executing it at the same time. 


Thanks for reading!

I have this conspiracy theory that everything aimed at women/girls is somehow better than the inverse aimed at a male demographic. This show perfectly encapsulates that theory of mine. Despite my avatar, I'm largely not a fan of harem shows. According to anime.plus its the lowest weighted genre score I have scored (in around 16 titles). Then why pray tell did I enjoy this? Is it that homoeroticism somehow turns me on? Well, no not really. 
Is it the story? Not exactly, the story can be summed up as: person ends up intimately situated with a number of members of the opposite sex who areinterested in them. Standard fare from what one might expect from a harem show. See, what sets apart Ouran High School Host club from its contemporaries in the harem genre isn't so much that the roles have been reversed as it's execution of the concept. Its the way the characters feel and interact with each other which makes all the difference. While I would struggle to describe your average harem protagonist in more than one sentence.


Our main character Haruhi Fujioka is different. Her strong personality is outlined when she refuses to allow certain misconceptions about her way of life to fly around, while at the same time not caring about what she deems trivial (such as stereotypical gender roles) choosing to care more about a person's actions than the situation they were born in (for somewhat obvious reasons). She's driven by her own ambitions and motivations while interacting with the world around her. The agency she has in the story despite the helpless situation that's she's put in clearly separates her from your standard harem protagonist that often feels like a passive agent in his story letting the world and by extension the people in it completely decide their direction in life (due to a lack of their own). 


That isn't to say that Haruhi herself is perfect far from it, though it's her character flaws that make her relatable and turn her into a fully believable human being which serves to set her apart from the crowd of 'bland, normal and unremarkable nice guys' that typically take the reigns of our main character. 


All of that is why this show is a lot more watchable. The fact that the boys around her would fall for her instead of the myriad of other girls in the school is infinitely more believable largely in part of her character and her backstory (which perfectly feed into each other). Speaking of the boys. I think I would go remiss in not mentioning that this is another area in which this show has proven itself to be superior to other shows in its genre. While the archetypes are there the author took the time to explore and explain why the character act the way they do and even provided some character growth for most of them despite the extensive cast of characters.


On the technical side, I feel the show is well animated though lingers a bit too much on still shots I assume for budget reasons. In regards to presentation, the previously mentioned homoerotic moments didn't really help the show as far as my enjoyment of it. I know why its there and hey if that's your thing don't let me stop you. I'm just saying It didnt serve to enhance my experience and possibly even diminished it slightly.


Overall: 7.4

From the year 2018, Ouran Host Club is a bit dated; not in art, but in concept. Or, perhaps, it was ahead of its time, in a way. Let me clarify. The show attempts parody and often achieves some level of subversion that is really charming. Other times, though, the tropes and stereotypes and gags leave a bitter sensation on my sensibilities. The first 10ish episodes really are a bit formulaic in a way that starts getting tiresome and problematic. Later in the show, development happens in plot structure and in character, making me really get into the show. As it is, this is alight 8--maybe a 7.5 if MAL allowed for it. But the latter half of the show--13 onwards--was very charming. 


I've seen reviews really criticize Ouran for being sexist and regressive and a failure at parody. I (mostly) disagree. The depiction of the two trans characters was not stellar, though I'd argue each had highlights that were done better than depiction I've seen in any anime shy of full on Wandering Son. But I got the sense that it wasn't talking down to women; all of the students were frivolous and flightful, not just the girls. All of them deluded themselves, one way or another, and were self important. It seemed to me that, while there were troughs were I found the depiction of the girls at the high school distasteful, most of the time, it seemed more like making fun of rich teenagers without a care in the world. 


I would have liked to see a bit more of Haruhi's intellect showcased, but generally speaking, I liked the show. If they had cut and tidied up the beginning and some of the gags, it could have been an easy 9 from me.

Ouran opened up the world of everything anime to me. While I had previously dabbled in one or two Studio Ghibli films, this show made me fall in love with anime comedy and continues to do so with every rewatch. 
Now, I'm not going to strut in here and say, "This is the greatest shows of all time! It's a masterpiece!", because that is far from the truth. The pacing is iffy. A lot of the jokes may go over your head. Some jokes are repeated way too much. The twin-cest is weird until you realize its a facade but it's still weird.
However, I willstrut in and say that I highly encourage for you, especially those of you who are squeamish of flowers and all things pink, to watch this show through. There is far more underneath the luxurious floral surface than you may initially realize.


I am not going to go through every aspect of the show and grade it. I will simply surmise that this show was thoroughly enjoyable to me. This is why:


-This show parodies Harem anime by actually looking into the stereotypes and proving that the characters don't fit into their cookie cutter roles as much you may have thought

-The wealthy v middle class contrast allows for hilarious scenarios and just great comedy

-Haruhi is a wonderfully sarcastic protagonist that doesn't fall in love with any of her potential suitors and always calls people out on their shit

-There is rather impressive character development mixed in with out of this world nonsense (i.e. alligators in an indoor water park? a convenient banana peel thrown for plot?) 

-The intro is a fucking jam


Overall, this show is all over the place. It's strangely chaotic, yet has moments that slow us down and allow us to appreciate the characters and their dynamic. I love this show. I love the outrageous characters and the real heart-aching moments that occur. Don't be scared away by all the roses. Instead, "KISS KISS FALL IN LOVE"!

This anime is probably the first to actually make me laugh out loud, the humor is packed in every episode. Haru chan is a very great character despite her being a girl pretending to be a boy, i feel as if she plays her part wonderfully. And the “romance”between Haru and Tamaki is adorably cute and hilarious. There’s not really much to say about this anime, just watch for yourself and you’ll see that’s it’s a total gem

I've watched Ouran Koukou Host Club a total of three times, and  it never gets boring, so here's what I think of the different elements of the anime
Story: 8.5ish out of 10
The plot is fairly simple and unique, meaning that there probably aren't much plot holes. Character development is scarce compared to the manga, but that's to be expected considering that it's a comedy and not meant to be taken all seriously, but the lack of character development still takes away from the show.
Art: 9/10
It follows a classic older manga/anime style; big eyes, big heads, but my one complaint is that characters all havesimilar head/nose shapes. The backgrounds are drawn well and it corresponds well with the feel of the current scene


Character: 8.5/10


Each character is unique (unless you compare the twins to eachother) and Tamaki acts a bit homosexual at times? The host club males all have stereotypical personalities, the flirty loud type (Tamaki) the nerdy quiet one (Kyouya) the tall strong, quiet one (Mori) the boy lolita type (Honey). It's easy to get a grasp of their personality and how they're like through the first few episodes of the series.


Enjoyment: 10/10


This is one of my favorite animes, and it never gets boring as I watch it over and over again, even if I know what's gonna happen already. If you haven't watched Ouran Koukou Host Club, then I'd strongly recommend it



PS: this is my first anime review so i might've not done a good job of writing it, sorrryy uwu

A word to define the show:
Funny.
this show is a masterpiece, a gem. It delivers its plot in such a way, that by the first 7 minutes of this show, you'll be laughing your ass off.This anime delivers a fresh take on Romantic Comedies. Haruhi, the female lead is very different from most shoujo female leads. She's sort of, lets just say ' TomBoyish' but not really tomboyish. you get what I mean? She's feminine but not Feminine at the same time. 
The show includes mild romance and often, sometimes completely disperses it by adding humor.
All in all, this is a funny and great show, thatjust so happens to be ranked 2 on my favourite animus.

I’m usually into different types of shows, so trying Ouran host club was a leap of faith. I found myself wanting to try something a little different. 
The first episodes completely sucked me in. It’s an interesting premise, and had me chuckling throughout the season. I liked to see how the social dynamics played out between the host club, their female visitors, and Haruhi as she played around with her gender fluidity. Tamaki is so dramatic(“Capricious is just another word for creative!!!”)and goofy, but he’s good-natured and part of what makes the show flow.
*However* Past the half way point, the episodes got kind of boring.or should I say repetitive? I know lots of people like the twins, but after a few episodes in a row only focusing on them, i got bored and literally fast forwarded past their parts.\n
This show was a trip to be honest. It’s not *that* deep, but sometimes you’re not looking for that. The characters’ personal stories can be a bit bland sometimes, but I enjoy the way the Ouran club interacts with each other when they do. They made me laugh despite myself.

Ouran is an anime for anyone who wants a laugh-out-loud-then-roll-on-the-floor-and-become-unable-to-breathe anime. It's absolutely hilarious! I mean, honestly. It is probably one of the best anime shows ever. It's got romance, drama, sad parts, hilarious parts, and great music. The opener and closer are great, and the rest of the music just suits the anime so well. The characters in Ouran are all complicated, but not in a heavy, dark, I-had-a-sucky-childhood way. They keep the plot going and the anime moving along. The art is also very well done.
So, to keep it short, Ouran is a  HILARIOUS must-watch anime. No excuses. Go watch it!
I loved almost every bit of it. The English dub is better than sub in my opinion. In short, If you want lots of laughs with cute characters then this is the show for you

I give this colorful romp a 89/100
Before I start my review, I'd like to say that I found this anime before I became totally ambitious about watching anime in Japanese. So yes, this was one of my very first TRUE anime (by true I mean dubbed in Japanese before it ever got licensed for the US market). I found it on it's first run in 2006, and I thought it looked nice so I checked it out. I had NO idea what I was getting myself into.
So, it's about Haruhi Fujioka, a young not-so-rich girl who gets a scholarship and goes to Ouran Academy, aschool for rich kids. After finding herself in debt she gets recruited by the school's host club run by very beautiful men, and she has to impress lots of girls (who don't know that she's a girl) so she can have her debt paid off.


Anybody that watched this and Fullmetal Alchemist (which I haven't. Don't kill me) will know that FMA and this are made by the same studio: BONES. Bones pretty much spoiled this anime with great animation, detailed backgrounds, wonderfully vibrant character movements, and pretty much everything else. It's just that good.


The soundtrack is great too, consisting entirely of classical undertones, violins, pianos, etc. It's not used just for drama, but for satire as well. Normally when comedies have BGMs to them, they're mostly just crude sound effects (like the ones in Ed, Edd, and Eddy, which is awesome). Ouran however uses its soundtrack well for comedy and drama as well as everything else.


Sure this seems like your typical reverse harem anime, but it is a LOT better than most harem anime. Why? Because although the characters are set to have some kind of stereotype at first, this anime parodies them and breaks the characters out of their molds at the same time. Not only that, it's got great execution, great comedy, great use of character development (which is something that most reverse harems lack), and a very interesting back story.


But what really made the show for me are the characters. Namely Haruhi, the lead female. She's so totally NOT your average reverse harem lead. She's TOTALLY uninterested in the guys trying to get her attention, doesn't know how to freshen herself up, knows what she wants to do in life, tries to make the best of what she has, and isn't a stereotypical damsel in distress. I would gush and gush about the other characters, but that'd take too much time. But I will say that they're all great, well developed, neatly fleshed out, and excellently portrayed.


This and Digimon Savers were the two anime that really got me ambitious about anime like I am now, but I think Ouran did it the best. It's a sweet, funny, and cute story that's basically a big pink frilly explosion of neat ideas, and a great one! If you're looking for a nice comedy that's not cliche or bland or anything like that, then go to the Ouran High School Host Club! The men will sweep you off your feet! I already got other people into this anime (including my childhood friend who's a BOY), so you'll like it too!

the funniest anime  i ever saw in my life . really , not only does it have a weird storyline but fantastic , superb , awesome charecters .from haruhi till honey it just takes your breath away . the story is based on a girl who is from a middle class family and gets scholarship to enter a grand high school . but things just dont work out , because the school is only for rich people like for woman who have too much time in their hands and boys who try to entertain them . so she goes to the host club thinkingits the music room and breaks a vase which is 8888888$  . she cannot pay it back so there was a condition  that she ould join the host club .

What can I say about this anime? IT'S ABSOLUTELY AMAZING! This anime never fails to make me laugh. The characters are full of energy and characteristics. Plus, Tamaki is my favorite character. He always make me laugh. Gosh, no anime has made me laugh so hard before. So if you're looking for a comedy anime, you should watch OHSHC. I promise you that it will be the number one anime on your list. :)

I remember when a friend of mine suggested that i watch this anime, i kept putting it off and off. I figured it would like every other reverse harem out there, with not much thought put into it. The first episode of this show was a revelation. it was the exazt oppoiste to what i was expecting, and i loved it. I loved every second of it. The story is sweet without being soppy, the comedy is funny without being too overdone, and the characters each have their own stories, which is fun to watch when they all combine. it is a fantastic anime andwell worth your time watching.

So when I was first read the description of this anime, I was a little skeptical about watching it. I read some of the reviews and that is the main reason I decided to watch it. When I started it, it didn't really impress me that much. The storyline was okay. Some of the characters are a little over the top but overall, their personalities mix together really well. While watching this, I found myself making myself watch the rest of the episode because it was so boring. A lot of the episodes were filler episodes, just telling you how each member became a partof the host club and Tamaki's relationship with them. \n
So i'm gonna start with some of the pro's. The anime is very entertaining. The over the top characters are a huge reason for the funny moments of this anime. The anime also has a wide variety of characters. There's the 'prince' Tamaki, The twins 'Twincest' Hikaru and Kaoru, the boy lolita Honey, the quiet tough guy Mori, and then the more level headed characters Kyoya and Haruhi. Each character also has a deeper past that may surprise you because of all their happy and bright personalities. The concept of a club that entertains girls is also a very interesting idea. \n
Now, some of the cons. One major con I had was the filler episodes. I don't know about you, but I like it when something interesting happens within an episode. It keeps me watching. That's what makes me want to watch the next episode and that's exactly what this anime was lacking. I found that after watching the next episode I wouldn't want to watch the next just for the reason that I didn't think it was going to be good. I also feel like, you needed to watch the filler episodes because they would reveal something about someone's past that would make you understand them more. That was the only major con, but just that one con made it so hard for me to finish this anime. \n
Overall, I don't think I will be rewatching this anime anytime soon. I would recommend this anime to someone wanting to just pass time though.

Ouran high school host club is a about a girl called haruhi fujioka who moves to a new upper class school. on her first day she trys to find a quiet place to study, stumbling upon the third music room she dicovers the host club, tamaki, kyouya, mori, honey and the twins hikaru and kaouru. she is mistaken for a boy due to her scraggy hair and 'comoners clothes' and is dragged into joining the club. eventually they find out she is a girl and try to protect her gender from the school.
Overall this anime has no plot but is a funny and romantic storythat any hirl can get into

Host Club !! you are now the new host!!
My first impression on this cute show is that a friend of mine let me borrow the manga. I got to be honest I got attached to this show like in a heart beat.
That's how fast you'll start to enjoy this show ,the characters,the songs.
I fell in love with the story and how HOT the guys in the anime where. Especially the Hitachiin twins, Honey m Tamaki and Haruhi those are and will always be my favorite in this show. This show really makes you fall in love ,laugh out of your mind,be worried but mostly onhow the main character will accomplish her debt on a vase.\n\n
The opening song and ending song are awesome. The ending.....it depends on your opinion , that counts I say it was awesome and worth re-watching ,over,and over again. Have fun on this cute story.

In my first year of high school (first year of middle school for Americans, I think?) I had a friend who got me into anime, although I only ever watched the most popular ones such as Naruto and Fairy Tail. By second year, I was out of that little phase I had and straight into my embarrassing emo phase.  However, a few months ago, I came across Ouran High School Host Club online and decided that it would do no harm to watch it.  Thanks to this anime, I was dragged completely willingly back into the world of anime.
Story 8/10
Ouran, while being setin a school with lots of attractive boys and a tomboy female main, was completely unique. Each episode brought it's own completely new lighthearted, sometimes emotional, plot line. The story was extremely easy to follow and the drama was nothing too cringe-worthy. I found myself laughing every single episode without fail.


Art 9/10


Coming from someone who knows next to nothing about art and styles of art, I found the art absolutely amazing! The animation was really fluid and pretty and it is quite clear that a lot of time and effort went into making this anime. 


Sound 9/10


I think the sound is one of my favourite things about the anime. The soundtrack consisted of all classical orchestra compositions which truly fit in with the atmosphere of the anime and I adore the ending song. The opening theme is not my favourite, but catchy and quite enjoyable, however that is all down to taste.

The voice actors (or Seiyuu; whatever you call them) where perfect for their roles and I truly couldn't think of anyway to make that aspect better.


Character 10/10


If you ask any of my friends, or have read any review for anything I write then you would know that characters and their development is probably the most important part for anything for me, and the characters in Ouran are still some of the best I have ever had the pleasure to get to know.  At first, all the males of the Host Club come across as stereotypical 'hotties' - the kind that I hate - but as the series progressed, we find out that there is so so much more to these boys than you could imagine. Their pasts get explained so effectively and you really see so much development in the characters (particularly the Hiitachin twins!!) as the anime goes on. Haruhi is such a wonderful heroine because of how well developed she is. She has her good points; kind, considerate, observant - but the thing that made her truly amazing were the fact she had flaws; sometimes unmotivated, defensive, impatient. 

Not only were the main characters great, but every single side character or character that appeared for a single episode were thought out and they were treated as well as the main characters. Their pasts were always explored and their personalities diverse and intricate. I felt emotions, whether they be happiness, sympathy or anger, for each and every one of the characters.


Enjoyment 10/10 

Overall 10/10


I've watched this anime three times since discovering it in December 2013 and I haven't gotten tired of watching Ouran in the slightest. The show makes me happy, makes me laugh and even cry at points (but then again, I get emotional about a lot of things) and it has easily made it's way straight up to the top of my favourites list.

First review so bear with me X).
Ouran High School Host Club eloquently combines humour, a whimsical and erratic style of artwork, and heartfelt themes to create an animated masterpiece that appeals to a wide array of genres.
I would usually opt for a more action based show, but the humour of the show absorbed my attention so vehemently that I was hooked completely and did not feel that there was any sense of lacking in spite of the absence of an abundance of action sequences. That being said, the few action scenes placed throughout the series were thoroughly satisfying :)
While the story line appears superficial atfirst, the show craftily weaves deeper meaning within each episode to beautifully create a touching episode arc. 

The show is conducted in such a manner that each character is allowed the opportunity to empathically reach out to the viewer through their trials and struggles. It is rare that a show possesses more than 3 round characters, yet in Ouran Host Club each character shares an ever-changing charisma unique to them that is practically tangible beyond the fourth wall (which is broken so wonderfully often in the show).


I was especially a fan of how the show managed to keep a light overall theme while still exploring more appreciable and meaningful topics and emotions. The show is a paradox in that the artistry keeps one on their toes and is full of erratically placed scenes and surprises, yet the storyline is familiar and easy to follow (This is what I believe allowed the show to remain lighthearted while investigating more serious emotions).


Before I wrap up here, I should of course also mention that The Host club was hysterical. I don't think I've ever laughed as hard from another show... It has raised the bar for satirical anime.


Lastly, I LOVE that Haruhi is a strong female lead set true to her beliefs. To me that is a prize within a romantic genre, so I was so pleased to follow Haruhi's story within the show.


Albeit- I am relatively  new to the anime genre in its entirety, from what I've watched so far, this show stands out among others. This is a show I will come back to watch when I need a good pick me up, or when I find my life missing the hilarity of all its beloved characters that fill it with such charisma. You will not easily leave my inner mind's theatre Ouran High School Host Club.


Thanks for reading this! It may not have been a perfect review, but I had a lot of fun writing it, so I hope it helps.

*Anime Legends Part 2*
Preface:
	This didn’t originally start out as an Anime Legends review, and I’m still not sure if this deserves a higher rating than Brotherhood, or Ping Pong the Animation, or my other 8’s, but during the process of writing this review I’ve come to terms with my love for this show, despite how somebody would perceive the show to be like, if they never watched an episode, and if he or she just read a synopsis of the plot. 
Story: 7/10
 	“Only those with excellent social standing, and those from filthy rich families, are lucky enough to spend their time here, at theelite, private school, Ouran Academy. The Ouran Host Club is where the schools handsomest boys with too much time on their hands, entertain young ladies who also have way too much time on their hands. Just think of it as Ouran Academy's elegant playground for the super rich and beautiful” -Tamaki Suou


 	Based off the premise of the story, I never would have thought that I would love many aspects of this show. I’m already not a huge fan of having a harem, but a reverse harem seemed like all it would be was oodles upon oodles of manservice, causing me to eyeroll into oblivion, but thankfully I was dead wrong. Now for a  while I was thinking that this could be one of my favorite anime series, it just does so much of what it strives to do so well in such a meta and original manner that I couldn't help but to admire what appeared at the start to be a reverse harem, problem of the week type of show. The story begins with commoner Haruhi Fujioka trying to unload and relax when she stumbles into music room #3, the home of the Ouran Host Club. And being her clumsy self she accidently breaks a vase which forces her to become their dog/servant in order to pay back her debt, but here’s the real twister he is actually a she, she just looks like a boy because of her short hair, and due to the fact that she never really wears anything girly or frilly. After that we see her relationship grow with the other members of the Host Club, with episodes diving into their individual backstories, and that is pretty much it. Besides paying off her debt there isn’t or wasn’t much of an old goal for the show, but they way they are able to conclude the series was thrilling and action packed but wasn’t all that satisfying. I mean this is more of a parody of the genres it emulates, but some sort of actual romantic payoff with the twins or Tamaki would have been nice, and they never even reveal to the rest of the class that Haruhi was a girl the whole time, I mean she is dancing in a dress near they end in public, but she is still shown wearing her boy school uniform. I mean she really doesn't care how people perceive her to be gender wise, and that is really great, but wouldn’t it be cool to see their reaction, or to wrap up some of the other character development that was left to dry when the series finished, but oh well. Most of the comedy comes from how delusional everyone in the show is besides Haruhi, and how Haruhi reacts to their grand delusion is hysterical, and how over the top the romance gets can be just insane and cheesy enough to get a few laughs. The only negative aspect to the comedy are the monkeys or whenever they slip on bananas peels, it isn’t funny it's just random and dumb, besides that though the comedy in this show is stellar. 


Characters: 10/10


	Haruhi is the main character, and definitely the most relatable, she always seems to get fed up with the other members, and her sarcastic comments whenever they are putting on a show for the ladies are gold. She doesn;t seem to mind what people perceive of her on the outside, because what's on the inside is much more important. She is a very perceptive person, who is able to see through pretty much anyone. She is the first one that the twins Kaoru and Hikaru really can connect to, since she is able to decipher between them so easily. She is often adored by the members of the club, and the girls customers who see him as a kind hearted and cute person. It’s a bit unbelievable that none of the girls customers were able to put two and two together but whateves. She is a very strong and independent person who is only really afraid of lightning/thunder. Even though she seems to be liked or admired by most she tends to like to keep to herself, and thinks about the simpler things like going to grocery store in order to take up a sale on chicken. She is often patronized by the members of the club for her less than stellar situation at home, but she stands up for herself and others quite often. For one line of dialogue in particular she kind of reminded me of Daria from the tv show Daria except was less pessimistic, I’m not sure if I have a single problem with her. She, being a commoner, is the butt of a lot of jokes, and due to how outragneous most of the club members acts she is a fantastic straight man. She is an amazing lead character, and whenever she isn;t on screen I wish she is. Also the title cards for each episode with her dubbed voice reading off the description was nice addition to the show. 


	Tamaki Suou, the renowned president of the Ouran Host Club, He is incredibly suave with the ladies when he wants to be, only wanting to see them smile, and brighten their daily lives. He seems to have no real dark side, and is almost childish in the way seeks to help others out or bring happiness to their lives if they call on the Ouran Host Club for help. While almost everyone he asked to join the Ouran Host Club was against it at first, he was able to warm them up to the idea, by saying just the right things, and by not giving up. He becomes obsessed with Haruhi after learning of her true gender, and he consistently comes to her aid, or rushes to her whenever anything happens claiming to be her father, or at the very least a father figure, which is really weird considering his real feelings for her. For a while all I could think of whenever he talked was Edward Elric considering how similar those two voices Vic Mignogna did, but that made him even more endearing to me, because of how I was able to hear a much more emotionally and silly version of Edward through Tamaki. He is an idiot, who becomes shell shocked whenever anyone disagrees with him, but at least he’s a graceful, loveable, idiot (who is also a killer piano player). 


 	Mitsukuni Haninozuka, is a third year student who is the boy lolita type, with a sweet tooth, and is pretty much an indestructible weapon, his backstory episode really added depth to his character, but he still comes off a little annoying to me, and pretty selfish at times overall. The Twins Kaoru and Hikaru Hitachiin are fantastic together and the mind games they are able to play on others is at times devlish. Their development, overall growth was interesting, with each brother coming out of his shell more and more, and trying to connect with others besides each other. Still the twincest weirds me out a bit (not actually twincest but kind of twincest, it’s pretty confusing to me). Takashi Morinozuka is the strong, silent type who acts like a bigger brother for Mitsukuni having a lot to do with their families master-servant relationship. She never really gets all that much development, which brought up in a hilarious fourth-wall breaking moment, so I can forgive it. Kyouya Ootori, is definitely the member of the group who is the most logical and intelligent, without him the club probably would have been burned to the ground long before Haruhi was forced into joining, and eventually becoming a full fledged member. He seems to act only if the situation is self advantageous, though Haruhi sees right through his cold act exposing his softer interior. These other members are pretty memorable on their own, first coming off as annoying and pretentious but they start become endearing the more they interact with Haruhi, really acting as the family that Tamaki always envisioned themselves as.  


Art Style/ Animation: 9/10


	The art definitely has the Shoujo style with large cutesy anime eyes, but I really like it for the most parts, it can get very expressive and cartoony at times. The show’s colors are very vibrant with a lot of pinks and blues. And there are a lot of great visual  showing how cheesily romantic the show gets at times  The backgrounds for the most part are extremely elegant and detailed. The club room, is as fancy and sophisticated as it gets. There is an obnoxious amount of cherry blossom and rose petals thrown around, whenever they enter the club and many transition or character actions utilize roses in the background. 


Music: 9/10


	The music throughout the show exudes extravagance, and it is for the most part quite serene and playful. It really compliments the rich and carefree lifestyle most of the students of Ouran lead. Most of the piano tracks are simple yet profound when played against the right backdrop. There are a few more theatrical and music I could see being played at a ballroom dance. The sound effects used are often colorful and very effective, most for a better comedic effect. Like whenever Tamaki is turned down, or the use of arrows to point out an object that will be really important in a couple moments. The opening is a cheesy, girl japanese rock track, and at first it seemed really generic or out place, but the more I listen to it the more endearing it becomes. It fits the fun and comedic vibe the show gives off very well, though it contrasts quite a bit from the OST. The closing harder rock track sounds almost like a parody song as if it was sung by one of the creators of South Park, still it rocks hard and that cheesy almost intentional badness really gets you excited to click play on the next episode.


Enjoyment: 9/10


	The Show is extremely entertaining, hilarious, and interesting despite what the show is about. The characters unique personalities are great in contrast with how normal, and logical Haruhi can be. I love pretty much everything that Ouran tries to do, but it never really connected with me emotionally. Ouran knows what it is, and what it wants to be, and it excels in that regard, but I’m at a crossroads with giving this series an actual rating. I really can’t decide with this show is just great, or if it is one of my favorite series, but I’ve seemed to view anime series with an emotional or deeper meaning as superior to those without it, but it isn’t fair to compare shows like Clannad: After Story or Steins;Gate to Ouran Host Club. As mainly a comedy in my eyes, Ouran is leagues above most comedies and slice-of-life high school shows, so fuck it. Ouran gets a 9/10. Fuck it, I don’t care if it's a reverse harem, I don’t care if it is extremely girly and adorable. I’m giving Ouran Koukou Host Club a 9/10.

This anime has taken my sanity. It's just to funny I just wanted to uggh.
First, this is a romcom, though for me it was more of a com. With each guy in this anime being a girl's steryotype in a boyfriend. The creators nailed in with each personality, even bringing the girl into the mix of it. 
Though with everyone being so different, they manage to get along as if family. At one point in the anime, one "Prince type" even calls himself daddy with the complete opposite being mommy, Yeah, it's a little messed up there.
I watched this with my sis, laughing the entiretime. So this anime is safe and enjoyable to watch with others. Of course it isn't just about the romcom part of the anime. It actually has a story line.\n\n
At first it was hard for me to actually pick up the storyline, though thanks the anime itself. Slowly but surely it was surfaced. \n\n
If you are a first timer, this one is a good starting point. Just because of the bright artwork and the character's personalities.

Before watching Ouran High School Host Club, I had read many positive reviews and lots of people calling it their 'favourite anime ever' etc, and since it came out nine years ago, I was quite late in watching it just recently. So, I started watching it with high expectations of it being a hilarious anime with great characters. In my opinion, it's a good anime with some likeable characters. For me, its the kind of anime that makes you smile when you watch it, and smile when you think back on it. But it's not a particularly exciting show, and at times it could bea little long winded. That's not to say you shouldn't watch it - but continue reading to find out what I liked about it!


Story: 7

If you don't know already, the story is about a girl, Haruhi Fujioka, who gets given a scholarship to 'Ouran Academy', a very expensive high school for rich people, basically. Haruhi is mistaken for being a boy on her very first day, causing her to be forced into the Host Club when she smashes an expensive ornament. In the Host Club, the members spend their time entertaining girls who have 'too much time on their hands'. While she is in the host club, she makes friends with the members, and each episode is mainly about different events they host in their club, their main priority being to bring happiness to all girls and such. Many of the episodes revolve around just a single character, which can be nice to get to know them personally. The main theme in this anime is comedy, but there's also a lot of seriousness when you get to learn about the mostly sad things the characters had to endure in the past. There's no serious romance in this anime, I guess you could say there's a bit of puppy love, but I don't think the characters even realise it when they start to like another character. I'm being vague, because I don't want to spoil anything. The reason I gave the story a 7 is because I personally, haven't seen an anime quite like this before, rather than focusing on high school life in general it is specific to school clubs and it also gives you a lot of insight into the character's pasts, so you can really get to know them. While the story was unique, some of the episodes could get a bit repetitive for me, which is why it is only a 7.


Art: 9

I'm definitely not an expert on what is good art and what isn't, but there was something really nice and 'refreshing', as anime characters would say, about the way the characters were drawn. Even though this anime is fairly old, the characters are all really good looking and very unique. Some of the scenes in this anime are really beautiful, there is a lot of bright colours used, especially pinks, giving more of a cartoony feel to it.


Sound: 9

The OP is strangely addictive, I find myself singing it all the time. Some of the music in this anime is beautiful, mostly piano based, but the show doesn't revolve around this as it is more focused on comedy.


Character: 7

Some of the characters I loved and some I found myself growing tired of them. But, that's just because of my own likes and dislikes in personality types, so you can decide that for yourself. In the host club, every member represents a different 'type'. For example, there is a princely type - and while he acts charming in the host club, his true personally is completely oblivious and he is always making a fuss - which did start to get on my nerves, after a while. Haruhi has to be one of my favourite characters. She is the normal type, she's kind, funny and genuine - I basically think she's nice to everyone. I don't want to go into too much detail on the characters, since they all have their own qualities about them and you will definitely find some that you like, and some that you dislike. Having said this, the bonds between the characters are definitely enjoyable.


Enjoyment: 7

I really did like this anime, but at times, the episodes became slightly tedious because of repeated jokes. For example, Tamaki, the blonde haired prince type, continuously calls Haruhi, the main character, his daughter, and overreacts when anyone goes near her. While this was funny at first, it quickly became boring. Some episodes focused on only one character, so if I didn't like the character.... the episode wasn't that great for me. However, the chemistry between the characters was great to watch. My two favourite characters, Hikaru and Kaoru, are really funny, so they made the show great to watch - and in my opinion, their past is the most interesting, so the episodes revolving around them were thoroughly entertaining. As I mentioned earlier, it all depends on which characters you like. But there will definitely be some, if not all, that you love. Some of the jokes made me laugh, like how all the host members are so clueless about life as a 'commoner' (as they call Haruhi), like they get excited over things they've never seen before such as instant coffee.

What can I say? An anime based on a stereotypical concept that girls should be entertained by some handsome boys? That would sound like something totally misogynous to reinforce an exasperated "machismo" culture.
Ouran Koukou Host Club (OHC) gives this first impression, and I should personally say I didn't like the first episoded because of that. However, as the anime went through, I was able to see  that I got a completely wrong image. OHC is an anime that adresses questions such as gender identity and makes an ejoyable satire of the various clichés that domain human idealist affective relationships. I must confess that Ilaughed a lot with Tamaki's obessivness,  the incestous Boy's Love relationship of Hikaru and Kaouro,  the coldness and utilitarism of Kyoya, etc. The "Hosts" are enjoyable creatoins that not only are able to make fun, but are also well good developed with a strong emotional background that shows this Host club is not only a matter to entertain, but rather unify.


However, the major credits that this anime has is its major and fabulous protagonist. Haruhi is a true genuine and marvellous character that makes a perfect synchronicity with all the other ones Haruhi is a true feminist character, a true heroine that challenges the fact that gender identity is irrelevant at the time a person wants to define himself (it is not a surprise that a girl dressed up like a boy was the most popular host among girls) and what really matters is the individual itself. It is beautiful to see the contrast between this silly and untrascendent girls and the only mayor female character of the show, who is the only one able to affect and understand mainly all the members of the club. The female-empowerment of this anime is just brilliant.


To end, this anime is a very interesting piece that I would not hesitate to recommend. It is, in fact, one of my recent discoveries that have let me a true sad-sensation at the time I had realized it has ended.

Even though I haven't seen this show in a while, I still would like to share my thoughts about one of my favorite shows of all time, Ouran High School Host Club. 
 You may be wondering why I'm doing a review of this show just out of the blue without any recent re-watching. Well that is actually quite simple to answer, I'm currently in the process of reading the manga and fairly often I enjoy going back and re-watching my favorite episodes from this anime. But anyway let's jump straight in.
 Ouran high school host club is the 2006 anime adaptionof the shoujo manga by Bisca Hatori. The main premise is a girl who looks like a boy on scholarship at a extremely rich school  and she breaks an expensive vase belonging to a group of young man who are a part of the host club. She is then forced to entertain female guests as a way to pay off her debt. Silly? Yes. Bad? HELL NO! This show manages to combine several well executed traits to set a literal gold standard for reverse harems to come. 


  So what makes this show so good, well let's start with presentation. The animation of ouran high school host club is very glossy, well polished, and nicely drawn. The movements are also fluent and the atmosphere of the anime shifts in a smooth fashion. As far as voice work goes this piece excels at this aspect. Several great English voice actors including Vic Mignogna who voiced Edward Elric in fullmetal alchemist. 


 I couldn't really give the story that high of a rating due to it being episodic comedy but there are some fine storytelling elements present here. And the comedy is handled very well and is entertaining.


Easily the strongest aspect of this show is the characters, the characters are all extremely well fleshed out. Screen time and depth is given to each character to ensure that you become invested and that you notice different traits overtime. The dynamic relationships between these characters are awesome and well realized. Some of the best character interaction is the twins, Haruhi and Tamaki, and Tamaki and Kyoya. A good amount of this show's characters focus on how they can be changed. By meeting someone else in your life you can be changed and have your personality developed. And this causes character diversity and for characters to have meaningful change and development over time and features real character and relationship depth. 


  The OST and opening and ending themes were well done and fit well with the show. Well composed themes in episodes arise and can have impact on an episode. Side characters aren't slacked on either because alongside our 7 main characters we have a satisfying bounty of side characters who also have good depth and support and grow alongside the main characters.


  My enjoyment of this show as you can tell is very high. And even though I watched this show a while ago I still remember several details of it and I still love it. I watched this show when I didn't really know a lot about the medium of anime and you can definitely say it had a profound effect on me.


 Overall OHSHC is a must watch for romance and reverse harem fans. It features fantastic and diverse characters, amazing animation and great English voice work. It also takes romance anime cliches and performs a smart parody of said tropes. So in hindsight Ouran High School Host Club, you must watch this, it's one of the most special anime I have ever seen.

This is the very best anime I've ever watched! It was the first I started watching and I'm grateful that it was. 
The story is completely original and I love that Haruhi (main character) is not falling all over the guys in the club like most animes. She is level-headed, straightforward and responsible for her age. 
All the guys in the club may seem very stereotypical at first but as you further down the episodes you discover they each have a past that made them who they are. 
 It is definitely a must watch!

Before I begin, I think it will help to break down the episodes and what they are about so if you don't like spoilers don't read:
Episodes one to four are just focused mostly on silly antics of the club since Haruhi was so new. 
Five to twelve focused on some character background with the twins, Haruhi and some useless side characters the club helped out.
Thirteen is just a stupid Disney parody filler.
Episodes fourteen to eighteen goes back to character backgrounds focusing on mostly Hikaru's feelings and Kyoya meeting Tamaki.
Nineteen I'm sure is a filler of a rival school
Twenty to twenty-two goes back to character backgroundsfocusing on the twins again and Mori.


Twenty-three focuses on Tamaki's feelings for Haruhi.


Twenty-four is Tamaki and Kyoya's background and how they met.


The last two episodes after that could be a one-hour special since that is where the real plot finally happens though even that is anti-climatic.


Moving on to the characters:


The stereotypical female lead is a smart honor student who isn't afraid of most things, is very observant to the point she can tell twins apart from each other but is so dense and clueless that she friend zones a lot of guys and doesn't even realize her own damn feelings.


And then you have this happy go lucky guy who is genuinely sweet, although an idiot and totally ignorant about the world he lives in. He's so dumb and dense that he thinks he loves the heroine as a father figure despite being a year older than her.......


Honey is a little boy who likes sweets and stuffed animals, takes afternoon naps and basically just acts like a baby despite being eighteen. He must have been sleeping when the puberty train passed by. He has a loyal, faithful dog named Mori who rides him around everywhere and only talks when need be.


Next, you have two twins who think they are so much better than everyone around them, they view the world as two types of people: idiots and them. Yeah because they are so smart they didn't know what the hell instant coffee was. Or an apartment unit for that matter. Freaking morons.


Then there is a smart guy behind the financial operations of the club. I don't have a problem with Kyoya, he was one of my favorite characters.


All that being said, there were quite a bit of episodes with a lot of humor. Some were funny, other times they tried too hard with the exaggerated reactions to some situations. There really is no plot. It's just one of those anime where each episode is its own story. The last episodes could have happened sooner, like around episodes twenty up to the end. I suppose it's no different from other harem anime. So if you like this kind of anime where something interesting happens the last few episodes then you might like this one. At least you will get some laughs along the way.

This one snuck up on me. I'm attracted to comedic slice-of-life for their airy quality, the way that, given time to breathe, a simple story can be elevated and achieve a kind of true, everyday beauty. This frees the characters to be better fleshed out as their development is the focus of the story, rather than the focus being on building a more classically structured narrative, where the characters are judged by their usefulness in the grand scheme of the series as well as on their personality. But there is no grand scheme in (slice-of-) life.
Ouran does all of those things. The series is oneof several superficial pleasures -- and by superficial I mean luxurious, extravagant pleasures: not only the richness in display, but the operatic/theatrical aesthetic, with a focus on the glow of... well, everything. It has the essential-to-the-genre scope of silly adventures, the travels and themes-of-the-week and pastiches & homages to different genres -- and does every single one of them gloriously.


But where it excels, where the series actually got to me, was the unexpected tragedy of these characters. Those adventures -- better put: the Host Club as a whole -- are slowly revealed, as the background and history of those characters are shown, as doomed escapism. These are characters who are prisoners of their own birth, boys born of wealthy and traditional families that give them no space to decide over their own lives -- and, also for this, they have an underlying darkness, an edge that keeps showing its face under their well-mannered and charming exterior. There is a subtle but constant exploration of how unhappy they were until the forming of the club, and an even subtler implication that this unhappiness has its roots in the social obligations imposed by Japan's society, and their status therein (...which kind of makes this a little about those poor, millionaire kids, but I think that's forgivable, since their aloofness to the lives of the commoners is one of the biggest sources of dramatic tension and humor). This subtext, of course, turns into text in the home stretch.


Of course, the series isn't (mostly) dramatic. Quite the contrary: there's a huge generosity to the characters that inhabit the school, the characters of the week whose involvement with the group helps them find true love, access their true feelings, or just to feel better about themselves. It's also very, very funny. But more than anything - and also better than anything - Ouran is this complicated, slow burning, love story: one, (kind of left alone to simmer) about how a devious twin seems to find his own self through love; and, two, how the revelation of Suou's tragedy (when he finally has a past/history) affects a series-long uninterested Fujioka. 


Fujioka is a great lead, her lack of interest in everything etc, but also her almost supernatural understanding of the people's feelings (she's got to be some kind of empath) is consistently charming. She can go from whatever-she's-there-too to perfect-thing-at-the-perfect-time, and this is one of the greatest strengths of the series -- which makes things more perfect when something that is hidden from her, and the only thing she seemed incapable to access via her keen observation, comes to light, and gives the series, finally, its romantic apex. And, even better, this forces all the characters to revolt against their condition and achieve some instance of freedom, in an all-out operatic ending



Loose thoughts:


- Monkeys throwing banana peels as an unstoppable force of chaos.


- Mori's very telling heritage of servitude to Hani's family.


- The implications of the ending promised such a great next arch! Which leads to my biggest complaint:


- Somehow this isn't a thousand episodes long?? THIS IS A TRAVESTY!! (Haha get it? Like Fujioka's dad? I'll show myself out)


MVP: The chotic-er-than-monkeys-throwing-banana-peels twins. Mostly for their really original relationship, which might be my favorite thing in the whole series.

This anime is basically a comedy, reverse harem anime. The sad thing is that there is no major romance between the characters....which defeats the whole purpose of a harem anime. 
If you think that a harem should be where there is a major romance between the characters then I DO NOT RECOMMEND. Unlike Special A, the end is very very disappointing. There is absolutely no major romantic moments in the anime because it's just guys flirting with girls. 
However, as a comedy anime, this would be a good anime. I dont knw why this anime has a high rating for harem because it obviously lacksthe whole concept of harem (lack of romance between the characters) but if you like comedy with some romance, homosexual moments, lots of scenes where guys flirts with girls, minor romance, then I WOULD RECOMMEND this anime! \n\n
Im just hating the romance and harem part, but the anime itself IS ENTERTAINING! So if you want to watch something out of boredom, this anime would be great!

“I don’t think it’s all that important. Why should I care about appearances and labels anyway? I mean, all that’s important is what’s on the inside right?”
Anime is an art medium that has no shortage of silly rom-com’s. Unfortunately, it also has no shortage of mediocre ones. This is something I had noticed when I was first getting into anime and slowly but surely converting me into being the otaku I am now. However, one anime I saw some time ago that I really loved was Ouran Highschool Host Club. From the first to last episode, the laugh-until-you’re-crying-from-laughter comedy, surprisingly mature and emotional story-lines, lovablyeccentric and very well written characters and unapologetic & frequent meta humour absolutely won me over. Of all the good or mediocre romantic comedies I have ever seen in anime, this one is one of my favourites. Why exactly? Well…


*Warning, some minor spoilers ahead. There is a summary at the bottom if you care about spoilers or don’t want to read the entire review..*


When it comes to writing, there are few things harder to nail than comedy. A multitude of elements all have to work synchronously including timing, atmosphere, witty punchlines and pushing a joke far without totally breaking the audience's suspense of disbelief. Ouran somehow manages to pull it off. It is incredibly not subtle in its jokes and pushing character archetypes to their extremities. Despite that, it works because of how they use these stereotypes situationally. It also has some great running jokes. 


One of the best recurring jokes is the fact that the Hosts (besides Haruhi) know very little of “commoner” goods or lifestyles. So every time that Haruhi (our heroine) brings one, it gathers a lot more attention than it deserves, making the other hosts both incredibly condescending and yet also genuinely giddish. In terms of both framing and comedy, this works so well because they have shown the characters to be unusually excited by such cheap and uninteresting goods, playing on the audience's expectations. 


Ouran also has some of the best comedic timing I have ever seen and the best example of this I can think of is one of the scenes I laughed the hardest in. This scene also shows all of Ouran’s best qualities when it comes to comedy.  This was when it looked like Haruhi was leaving the club for a equally hilarious and ridiculous Zuka club, who seemed to be a female parallel of the Host Club. The plan they finally decided on was for themselves to dress up as females, as they thought that appealing to her feminine side would convince her to stay in the Host Club. 


Now what I think works so well here and for many of the other jokes is how they unite taking a joke to hyperbolic levels of absurdity and still having it make sense for the characters to do in the first place. We have seen a lot of scenes of the Hosts dressing up in ridiculous and expensive looking costumes, so it isn’t too outlandish or jarring to see them dress up in drag. It also works as situationally, she has been hanging out with a lot of dudes due to her debt. It wouldn’t be totally out of the question for Haruhi to want to hang out with girls either, despite the fact that she doesn’t really care about that. Lastly, there was the pure shock factor too. Since it wasn’t foreshadowed or telegraphed, there is a lot of genuine surprise when you do see them looking very ladylike (at least, more than usual).


Even though Ouran is gut-bustingly funny, what I think gets unfairly overshadowed is how good some of the more emotional scenes are written and the close bonds (sometimes a little too close) they share. As the anime moved into its second half, the narrative got considerably more serious. Ouran delved into the sadder or unfortunate circumstances that some of the Hosts were dealing with. It tackles a wide variety of common problems that adolescents deal with as they grow into adulthood, including acceptance from family, dealing with a strict family that has already decided your future or even loss of close family members.


I honestly thought that Ouran was best when it was taking the goofy characters and having them mature and grow past their problems. It was written in a way to not only make these super rich characters relatable to (mostly) anyone else watching but it also made them more than just the tropes that the comedy often confined them too. They had balanced both the more serious and dramatic moments very well with plenty of great jokes and hilarious situations.


If I really had any complaints about the writing, it would probably be the ending. Now the last few episodes were easily some of the best in the entire show. It for the most part brought some sort of conclusion to the main protagonists arcs and implied a potential romance blossoming… key word there was “implied”. Because the anime was airing while the manga wasn’t really done, there was only so much they could do about the ending. But since it is an adaption, comparisons to both the anime and manga ending are inevitable and the manga's ending was honestly far better. It provided a final resolution to the characters while resolving the romance as well and is by far my favourite part of Ouran (in either the anime or manga). 


But no matter how good your writing is, I believe the writing is often only as good as the characters and honestly, I think the characters are Ouran’s biggest strength.


Haruhi Fujioka is easily one of the best female protagonists I’ve seen in a shojo anime. It’d be one thing for her just to be sorta tomboyish and broke as an obvious foil to the frivolous and rich Hosts. However, Haruhi is much more than just your atypical Shojo protagonist; she also is just an excellent character in her own rights. What makes her character work so well isn’t just her non judgmental personality or her keen emotional insight; its how much of a positive influence she is on her peers.


As the show heavily implies, she and the Hosts live in two different worlds. Haruhi helps both worlds see more eye to eye. She helps humble them and be kinder to others (thus being better Hosts) and they help her normally anti-social personality to open up more, teaching her to also have fun along the way.  Which brings me to my personal favourite character in Ouran, Tamaki Suoh. 


Tamaki’s character development in some ways is rather subtle. He starts out being overly dramatic and downright obnoxious and in many ways, that doesn’t necessarily change.  At first, he just sorta plays the silly king/jester who is often the punchline to many jokes. As the tone in the show changed to focus more on character drama, we started seeing Tamaki for who he really is. 


Deep down past his obnoxious and goofy facade, Tamaki is easily the most selfless, compassionate and in many ways the smartest/most insightful Host. He was often able to understand his friends emotions even better than they were able to and hardly ever seriously asks for reward or acknowledgment in return. And when Tamaki and Haruhi were together, you were really able to see each other bring out the best of the other, making for a great romantic connection between the two.


 Another notable friendship is the one he has with Kyoya. Tamaki managed to identify Kyoya’s inner turbulence he was dealing with because of his family, resulting in Kyoya being honest with what he really wants and even expressing himself in the way of his choosing. Lastly, another smaller reason why he stands out as the best character was that Tamaki did all this while still dealing with a mother who is missing and a very strict, cruel and selfish grandmother. 


Outside the main cast, there are two more characters I’d like to briefly touch on; they are the famous Hitachin twins, Hikaru and Kaoru. Their character arc primarily deals with their own isolation and how to interact with others. Hikaru (my favourite of the two) later on is shown to be rather emotional and immature, reinforcing his lack of consideration for others feelings. The best example of that is when Hikaru goes out on a date with Haruhi. He gets consumed by jealousy and even at one point, abandons the date in Haruhi’s time of need. Yet he still came back and was there to help her when she needed it. That was easily my favourite Hitachin bros scene as well as one of my favourite in the anime. 


The music in Ouran wasn’t super noteworthy, as it’s mostly just classical music with original tracks occasionally. Despite that, there are definitely some solid tracks that I found myself returning to. My personal favourite is the piano version of Sakura Kiss (the opening theme). It played during some emotional moments of the anime and it worked very well, enhancing the scene in the anime and bringing back memories of Ouran listening to just the track itself. The opening theme is also catchy as hell and brings a smile to my face everytime I hear it. 


From an art and voice acting perspective, Ouran is also very good. The animation and art direction was fantastic as usual by Bones, using lush, vivid colours while keeping true to the original artstyle of the manga. I can still remember the plethora of roses whenever the hosts are charming their guests. The voice acting was also spectacular. Caitlin Glass does a fantastic job as Haruhi, embodying all her snark and subtle compassion and fear buried inside. Vic Mignogna was amazing as Tamaki, embracing all of Tamaki’s silliness and obnoxiousness wholeheartedly in his performance. Other notable performances include Travis Willingham as Mori and Todd Haberkorn as Hikaru.  


Summary: 


Ouran High School Host Club is a fantastic standalone anime. While it’s last episode pales in comparison to the end of the manga (as it wasn’t finished), it still managed to balance hilarious comedy with great emotional drama. Its characters are incredibly loveable and memorable even years after watching Ouran for the first time. Honestly, I highly recommend watching this before reading the manga, as I think that it's the best way to experience Ouran for the first time. Afterwards, read or purchase the manga and read for the definitive ending, as it’s worth it for that ending alone.
